item.title: 1308 NOTES OF SOME WANDERINGS WITH THE SWAMI VIVEKANANDA
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / NOTES OF SOME WANDERINGS WITH THE SWAMI VIVEKANANDA [Excerpts from the book by Sister Nivedita] Note: In the following work only those extracts which present Swami Vivekananda’s ideas or direct quotations have been printed. Descriptions marking the background context of these talks have also been retained for the sake of clarity and continuity. Ellipses mark the deleted portions.

item.title: 1309 FOREWORD
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / PLACE: Different parts of India. TIME: The year 1898. Beautiful have been the days of this year. In them the Ideal has become the Real. First in our riverside cottage at Belur; then in the Himalayas, at Naini Tal and Almora; afterwards wandering here and there through Kashmir — everywhere have come hours never to be forgotten, words that will echo through our lives forever, and once, at least, a glimpse of the Beatific Vision.

item.title: 1310 CHAPTER I
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER I THE HOUSE ON THE GANGES PLACE: A cottage at Belur, beside the Ganges. TIME: March to May, 1898. Of the home by the Ganges the Master had said to one, “You will find that little house of Dhira Mata like heaven, for it is all love, from beginning to end. It was so indeed. Within, an unbroken harmony, and without, everything alike beautiful — the green stretch of grass, the tall cocoanut palms, the little brown villages in the jungle, and the Nilkantha that built her nest in a tree — top beside us, on purpose to bring us the blessings of Shiva.

item.title: 1311 CHAPTER II
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER II AT NAINI TAL AND ALMORA PERSONS: The Swami Vivekananda, Gurubhāis, and a party of Europeans and disciples, amongst whom were Dhira Mata, the “Steady Mother”; one whose name was Jaya; and Nivedita. PLACE: The Himalayas. TIME: May 11 to May 25, 1898. We were a large party, or, indeed, two parties, that left Howrah station on Wednesday evening and on Friday morning came in sight of the Himalayas.

item.title: 1312 CHAPTER III
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER III MORNING TALKS AT ALMORA PLACE: Almora. TIME: May and June, 1898. The first morning the talk was that of the central ideals of civilization — in the West, truth; in the East, chastity. He justified Hindu marriage customs as springing from the pursuit of this ideal and from the woman’s need of protection, in combination. And he traced out the relation of the whole subject to the philosophy of the Absolute.

item.title: 1313 CHAPTER IV
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER IV ON THE WAY TO KATHGODAM JUNE 11. On Saturday morning we left Almora. It took us two days and a half to reach Kathgodam. . . . Somewhere en route near a curious old water-mill and deserted forge, the Swami told Dhira Mata of a legend that spoke of this hill-side as haunted by a race of centaur-like phantoms, and of an experience known to him by which one had first seen forms there and only afterwards heard the folk tale.

item.title: 1314 CHAPTER V
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER V ON THE WAY TO BARAMULLA PERSONS: The Swami Vivekananda, Gurubhais, and a party of Europeans and disciples, amongst whom were Dhira Mata, the “Steady Mother”; one whose name was Jaya; and Nivedita. PLACE: From Bareilly to Baramulla, Kashmir. TIME: June 14 to 20, 1898. JUNE 14. We entered the Punjab next day, and great was the Swami’s excitement at the fact.

item.title: 1315 CHAPTER VI
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER VI THE VALE OF KASHMIR PERSONS: The Swami Vivekananda and a party of Europeans and disciples, amongst whom were Dhira Mata, the “Steady Mother”; one whose name was Jaya; and Nivedita. PLACE: The River Jhelum — Baramulla to Srinagar. TIME: June 20 to June 22. “It is said that the Lord Himself is the weight on the side of the fortunate!

item.title: 1316 CHAPTER VII
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER VII LIFE AT SRINAGAR PLACE: Srinagar. TIME: June 22 to July 15, 1898. In the mornings we still had long talks as before — some-times it would be the different religious periods through which Kashmir had passed, or the morality of Buddhism, or the history of Shiva-worship, or perhaps the position of Srinagar under Kanishka. Once he was talking with one of us about Buddhism, and he suddenly said, “The fact is, Buddhism tried to do, in the time of Ashoka, what the world never was ready for till now!

item.title: 1317 CHAPTER VIII
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER VIII THE TEMPLE OF PANDRENTHAN PERSONS: The Swami Vivekananda and a party of Europeans and disciples, amongst whom were Dhira Mata, the “Steady Mother”; one whose name was Jaya; and Nivedita. PLACE: Kashmir. TIME: July 16 to 19, 1898. JULY 16. It fell to the lot of one of the Swami’s disciples next day to go down the river with him in a small boat.

item.title: 1318 CHAPTER IX
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER IX WALKS AND TALKS BESIDE THE JHELUM PERSONS: The Swami Vivekananda and a party of Europeans and disciples, amongst whom were Dhira Mata, the “Steady Mother”; one whose name was Jaya; and Nivedita. PLACE: Kashmir. TIME: July 20 to July 29, 1898. JULY 20. . . . . . . That morning the river was broad and shallow and clear, and two of us walked with the Swami across the fields and along the banks about three miles.

item.title: 1319 CHAPTER X
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER X THE SHRINE OF AMARNATH PLACE: Kashmir. TIME: July 29 to August 8, 1898. JULY 29. From this time we saw very little of the Swami. He was full of enthusiasm about the pilgrimage and lived mostly on one meal a day, seeking no company much, save that of Sādhus. Sometimes he would come to a camping-ground, beads in hand.

item.title: 1320 CHAPTER XI
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER XI AT SRINAGAR ON THE RETURN JOURNEY PERSONS: The Swami Vivekananda and a party of Europeans and disciples, amongst whom were Dhira Mata, the “Steady Mother”; one whose name was Jaya; and Nivedita. PLACE: Kashmir — Srinagar. TIME: August 9 to August 13, 1898. AUGUST 9. At this time the Master was always talking of leaving us.

item.title: 1321 CHAPTER XII
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CHAPTER XII THE CAMP UNDER THE CHENNAARS PERSONS: The Swami Vivekananda and a party of Europeans and disciples, amongst whom were Dhira Mata, the “Steady Mother”; one whose name was Jaya; and Nivedita. PLACE: Kashmir — Srinagar. TIME: August 14 to August 20, 1898. AUGUST 14. It was Sunday morning and next afternoon the Swami was prevailed on to come up to tea with us in order to meet a European guest who seemed to be interested in the subject of Vedanta.

item.title: 1322 CONCLUDING WORDS OF THE EDITOR
item.description: Home / Complete-Works / Volume 9 / Excerpts from Sister Nivedita’s Book / CONCLUDING WORDS OF THE EDITOR From Ganderbal the Swami returned by the first week of October and announced his intention of leaving for the plains in a few days for urgent reasons. The European party had already made plans to visit the principal cities of northern India, e.g., Lahore, Delhi, Agra, etc., as soon as the winter set in.
